Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the (11) VH-3D, (8) VH-60N, (1) UH-3D, and (1) UH-60N, currently in service. Initial Sundown efforts for these aircraft are to begin the first quarter of FY 2021. VH-92A Total Aircraft Inventory projected to be 23 by FY 2025 consisting of two Engineering Development Models and four System Demonstration Test Articles purchased with RDT&E funding PE 0604273M and 17 with APN-4 BLI 0455 procured. The overall goal of the budget in FY 2021 is to continue efforts in accordance with the modification strategy to maintain the VH-3D, VH-60N, and commence modification efforts for the VH-92A. 

OSIP 014-02: Communication Suite Upgrade, completes the incorporation of the Wide Band Line of Sight capability by finishing the Phase IV communication network upgrades and Global Positioning System enhancements.  

OSIP 016-08: Structural Enhancement Program, conducts VH Service Life Extension Program installations on the VH-3D and VH-60N. 

OSIP 006-21: VH-92A Improvement Program, provides for the preparation and incorporation of Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) that are based on added capability and correction of deficiencies, and the implementation of those changes to sustain and improve VH-92A operations. A variety of factors will be addressed including communication, navigation, weight, and safety to remain mission relevant. These modifications will also improve readiness, increase aircraft availability, and decrease operating costs.

Justification.val: In FY 2021, the Wide Band Line of Sight (WBLoS) will be continuing Phase IV of the effort for seamless transitions between Ground Entry Points, and implements enhanced tracking Through the Rotors capability in order to provide greater access to the NC2/3 networks and provide a robust Fault Isolation/Fault Detection system to the user. The Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) procurement and installations started in FY17 and will run through FY 2023. The SLEP effort is being installed in parallel with the Special Progressive Aircraft Rework (SPAR) effort, and must follow the SPAR schedule. The VH-3D Cabin Interior modification will complete installation efforts in FY 2020. The VH-92A Improvement Program will begin improvements and modifications to the SDTA aircraft and subsequent aircraft after they are delivered.

Name.@footnote: The increase in FY 2021 from FY 2020 is required to complete the final integration of the WBLOS system software upgrades into aircraft OFPs, perform system integration, ground and flight testing of both the VH-3D and VH-60N Phase IV software.
Cost element 3.9: FY 2021 Other support funding is required to update publications for pilot use to reflect Phase IV software updates.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: VH-60 Comm Upgrade (WBLoS) Hydra Light Systems

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  In support of the Senior Leaders Communications, a Wideband Line of Sight (WBLoS) system is required. Prior year efforts include the FM (YZ) radio replacements on the VH-3D and VH-60N aircraft to maintain crypto security requirements, as well as all related software/firmware modifications. In FY 2016 procurements commenced for a new radio, antenna, associated accessories, aircraft Operational Flight Programs (OFP) and aircraft integration.  

WBLoS consists of two systems: Hydra Light and Crisis Management. The Hydra Light system consists of a radio, antenna, and amplifier (RFE) that provide the means for a Voice over IP (VoIP) call to be made using the Phoenix Air-to-Ground Communications Network (PAGCN) structure. The Crisis Management system is the router, call manager, and High Assurance Internet Protocol Encryptor (HAIPE) required to connect into the TS/SCI network controlled by DISA. Due to the unique challenges of the aircraft platform (limited space, weight, power, cooling, etc), the WBLoS effort was set up in phases to allow for the hardware development and maturation of technology, which is then employed through phases via software modifications to the radio and/or ground equipment after initial installations. Phase III of the four phase WBLoS effort began in FY 2017 and included the Non Recurring Engineering (NRE) for an upgraded software OFP that will provide the capability for a single WBLoS Terminal to communicate with more than one Ground Entry Point (GEP) at a time in order to minimize transition time between GEPs. It also included the testing and verification of that software. Phase IV, began in FY 2019 and continues through FY 2021.  Phase IV includes a network upgrade to reduce anticipated packet routing delays due to limitations of Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) protocol when transitioning from GEP to GEP. Global Positioning System (GPS) enhancements support the VH requirement of seamless transitions between GEPs. Development and deployment of enhanced capabilities through phases (via software and modifications to the radio and/ or ground equipment) continue after initial installations. As of 22 April 2016, the VH-3D and VH-60N WBLoS communication capability efforts received a Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Navy signed exception to the prohibitions of 10 USC 2244a relating to the modification of aircraft within five years of retirement and disposal. 


The increase in FY 2021 from FY 2020 is required to complete the final integration of the WBLOS system software upgrades into aircraft OFPs, perform system integration, ground and flight testing of both the VH-3D and VH-60N Phase IV software. The FY 2021 effort also includes the incorporation of all previous defects from FY 2020 testing, a Formal Qualification Test (FQT), and a Fleet releasable software which includes communication network upgrades and GPS enhancements.  Upon completion of the software, final data will be delivered and incorporated into publications for the operators and maintainers.


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  In FY 2013, the Deputy Secretary of Defense (DEPSECDEF) initiated the requirement for the WBLoS capability. Research and development efforts began in FY 2014 for this effort; the procurement efforts began in FY 2016. Non recurring engineering efforts for Phase III began in FY 2017. Phase IV software upgrades began in FY 2019.


Notes:
1. The Communication Upgrade (WBLoS) A-kits are being installed via a contractor field modification team.

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 3.7: The Other Support across the FYDP is required for labor for the installation of the SLEP kits during SPAR.
Cost Element 1.1.1: One VH-60N SLEP Kit procured in FY 2015 was previously installed as the validation kit in FY 2017.
Cost Element 1.1.2: One VH-3D SLEP Kit installation shifted into FY 2020 due to aircraft availability and installations being quicker than anticipated.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The VH Structural Enhancement Program consists of the efforts to implement aircraft safety of flight structural modifications to extend the service lives of the VH-3D and VH-60N airframes.  The VH-3D and VH-60N must stay in service to support mission needs until the completion of the fielding of the VH-92A aircraft.  In order to meet the usage requirements, a Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) was established to implement the safety of flight upgrades identified in the Service Life Assessment Program (SLAP).  The SLEP extends the service life of the VH-60N and VH-3D by 4,000 hours.

FY 2021 increase from FY 2020 is required to complete additional VH-3D and VH-60N SLEP installations.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Non-Recurring Engineering for the VH-3D and VH-60N Service Life Extensions began in FY 2012.  The VH-3D SLEP kits were procured in FY 2013 via a Life of Type procurement due to lack of component part availability.  The VH-60N SLEP Kit procurement began in FY 2015.  Validation and Verification efforts occurred in FY 2017. Installs are to follow the Special Progressive Aircraft Rework (SPAR) schedule which began in FY 2018.

Notes:
1. VH-60N Kits have a 11 month production lead time. Kits must be available prior to the aircraft being inducted into SPAR. 
2. The Other Support across the FYDP includes labor for the installation of the SLEP kits during SPAR.

Sikorsky Aircraft Corp - Cabin Interior Redesign

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: VH-3D Cabin Interior Redesign Kit

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  
This Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program provides for the readiness of the VH-3D and VH-60N Presidential Helicopters. Funds will be utilized to manage and prepare, process, and incorporate Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) and implement changes to sustain and improve all Executive Helicopter Series system readiness including safety, mission availability, structural integrity, component (avionics/systems) reliability, maintainability, operational weight, performance, and obsolescence conditions as they arise. This program contains the upgrade of Air Vehicle Support Equipment and technical data to support VH unique Air Vehicle requirements. This upgrade effort will install new operating systems, replace obsolete components and core computers, test equipment and basic test program hardware.  The Cabin Interior upgrade program for the VH-3D reduces aircraft operational weight, replaces obsolete electrical components, upgrades the fuel system and improves maintainability. Cabin Interior installation efforts include the depopulation of the aircraft and removal of current aircraft interior to ready the aircraft for the installation of the new interior kit, as well as the installation of the new interior kit. As of 18 February 2016, the VH-3D Cabin Interior Modification effort received a Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Navy signed exception to the prohibitions of 10 USC 2244a relating to the modification of aircraft within five years of retirement or disposal.

FY 2020 completes this OSIP. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: VH-3D Cabin Interior Upgrade Non-Recurring Engineering efforts began in FY 2014. The validation kit procurement was contracted in FY 2014 and was delivered in FY 2016. The validation installation was completed in FY 2017. Cabin Interior kits will be installed via a contractor field modification team and on-site support at the Presidential Helicopter Support Facility in Patuxent River, MD.

DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: In order to meet the requirement of providing safe and timely transportation for the President, Vice President, and other parties as directed by the Director of the White House Military Office (WHMO), and in support of the alert and contingency mission requirement of the WHMO Operations Plan, a VH-3D Cockpit Upgrade program has been established to extend the VH-3D service life requirements.  The VH-3D Cockpit Upgrade eliminates pending obsolescence and supportability issues with key avionics components and brings the VH-3D in compliance with mandated avionics capabilities (Communication Navigation Surveillance/Air Traffic Management, Terrain Awareness Warning System/Ground Proximity Warning System). In addition, an upgraded cockpit improves system safety, reduces pilot workload and training requirements.  The baseline upgrade includes night vision compatibility and related cockpit lighting, GPS moving map functionality, and satellite weather feed, bringing the VH-3D in line with VH-60N capabilities. Modern, common avionics equipment will reduce logistics cost and increase reliability. 

FY 2019 completes this OSIP.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Procurement efforts for the VH-3D Cockpit Upgrade began in FY 2012.  Procurement for the Cockpit Upgrade Lighting kits began in FY 2016. The GPS update began in FY 2018. Operational Flight Program Software (OFP) upgrades for the Cockpit Upgrade program are ongoing to support the upgraded hardware systems.

Notes:
1. The Cockpit Lighting Upgrade kits will be installed at O-level by the squadron at HMX-1 as aircraft are available.
2. The DTU-7000 effort within the FY18 VH-3D Cockpit Upgrade (OSIP 10-12) software line has been cancelled.

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 3.1: Data Costs are required to update Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs) and publications to reflect forced retrofit changes.

Cost Element 3.2: Software costs are required for upgrades/modifications to the Mission Communications System (MCS) software that includes the DEPSECDEF mandated requirement for Wide Band Line of Sight (WBLoS) capability for all strategic communications platforms. FY 2021 Software costs represent follow-on, upgrade/modification effort for future communications capabilities currently being developed.

Cost Element 3.3:  Training Equipment costs are required to ensure training devices delivered to the fleet (flight trainer, maintenance trainer, system emulation maintenance trainer, and courseware) are concurrent with aircraft configuration.

Cost Element 3.6: Other Support costs are required for technical oversight, associated data updates, field activity, organic depot, and software support. Increase to this cost element throughout the FYDP is required to adequately provide the support to modification efforts which increases as the Aircraft inventory increases with the Production aircraft being delivered.
Cost Element 1.1.1: There are two Mission Communication System Server Hardware kits per aircraft.
Name.val: 1.1.1) Mission Communication System Server Hardware - Organic

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 1.2.1:  Installation Kits N/R costs are required for the Airframe and Avionics ECP preparation, tooling, and Val/Ver for correction of deficiencies.  Costs are increasing due to the varying number of expected NRE efforts and the quantity of A/C requiring correction of deficiency retrofits.

Cost Element 2.2.1:  Installation Equipment N/R costs are required for Airframe and Avionics installation equipment for correction of deficiencies.  Costs are increasing due to the varying number of expected NRE efforts and the quantity of A/C requiring correction of deficiency retrofits.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Method:: Installation Name: Sikorsky Installs for Shipboard Interoperability and ADSB Out efforts

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: The VH-92A provides safe, reliable, and timely transportation for the President, Vice President, Foreign Heads of State (HoS), and other official parties as directed by the Director of the White House Military Office (WHMO). VH-92A Improvement Program provides near and long-term improvements to the fleet, focusing on documented deficiencies related to mission systems, maintainability, and incorporates pre-planned product improvements defined in the VH-92A Capabilities Development Document update in lieu of a Capability Production Document. These modifications and selected component changes are being accomplished by depot level maintenance or field retrofit. Funds will be used to manage, prepare, process and incorporate airframe and avionics Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) based on added capability and corrections of deficiencies, and implement those changes to sustain and improve VH-92A operations and will be identified in the P3A as they are approved. ECPs will be implemented to coincide with resources and aircraft availability.  

AIRFRAME ECPs: Airframe corrections include all structural components, mounts, cowlings, landing gear, fuselage and various dynamic components. Planned effort includes Shipboard Interoperability, which allows for mandated shipboard operations.

AVIONICS ECPs: Modifications, other than structural deficiencies, are required to ensure safety of flight, aero-performance and maintainability. Avionics systems corrections include aircrew avionics, data, displays, controls, flight management systems, avionics management systems, navigation and safety systems, and communication systems. Planned efforts include upgrade of mission communication system server hardware (2 boxes per aircraft), Mission Communications System (MCS), Enhanced Visual System (EVS), and Automatic Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADSB) Out. ADSB Out efforts are to comply with Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandates to improve aircraft navigation in national airspace. EVS are improvements required to increase situational awareness outside of the aircraft during flight operations. MCS consists of all narrowband and wideband radios, intercoms, user interfaces, and control systems necessary to support command and mission communications requirements.


FY 2021 efforts include upgrades for Mission Communication System Servers, Shipboard Interoperability, and ADSB Out. The support costs are required for technical oversight, associated data updates, field activity and logistics support of the modification kit procurements, software activities, and Training Equipment efforts.

Aircraft modifications increase to match Total Aircraft Inventory each year.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The Milestone B Acquisition Decision Memorandum was signed 17 April 2014 and the VH-92A contract for the Engineering and Manufacturing Development (EMD) phase and priced options for production was awarded on 7 May 2014.  The VH-92A program conducted a Milestone C review on 30 May 2019. The Acquisition Decision Memorandum was signed on 7 June 2019. Three of four System Demonstration Test Articles (SDTA) aircraft have delivered during EMD, with the last delivering May 2020, and will be used for Initial Operational Test and Evaluation (IOT&E).  The SDTA aircraft will be transitioned to operational use after completion of IOT&E in FY 2021.  This OSIP is a new start in FY 2021 to begin improvements and modifications to the SDTA aircraft and subsequent VH-92A aircraft after they are delivered.  The VH-92A program will have a total of 21 operational aircraft by FY 2023.

VH-3D Lift Improvement Program (LIP) OSIP 011-06 completed in FY 2012 and has been moved to In-Active OSIPs.
VH-60N Cockpit Upgrade OSIP 009-02 completed in FY 2016 and has been moved to In-Active OSIPs.
VH-3D/VH-60N Trainer Conversion OSIP 009-11 completed in FY 2016 and has been moved to In-Active OSIPs.
